content:
This is really not a fair reverse clash.
I just got it then and I managed to solve it because of Ruby's useful prime_division method and then just tweaking my solution for your test cases.

I don't think you can expect people to reverse engineer such a complicated problem involving number theory and co-primality. I recommend disabling Reverse.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this is clever and informative (for those of us forgetting our maths). I think it will challenge some users to compute in 5min, but it will be a good challenge as runtime is rarely an issue in clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is largely doable in 5 minutes if you know a little about number theory (you know that you can find all divisors by iterating between 1 and √n), and if you know you can use a method to find the GCD (in Python, math.gcd)

I added "Size of code" mode, in order to give a little more time.

I added "Reverse" mode too, it is easy to see that by multiplying the output you get the input, you just need the to figure out what is the expected decomposition.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept the contribution because this challenges logical thinking and introduces new concepts

This might be a bit much for clash of code. Getting the rules (passing the first 6 tests/validators) is very doable, but getting code to not time out on 7 and especially 8 takes more work than most clashes.
Maybe consider changing the constraint on n? That feels like a bit of a cheat, but not sure what else to suggest.

In fact, you should revise your tests and constraints now that I look at them.
If any number is accepted, then you could choose 1 and n each time and it should be accepted each time (1 and n are always coprime and 1 * n = n)
Add a constraint a > 1 and b > 1. You may add it in the Goal too.

Hi ! 
You could add some little things to make it more understandable :
* Make it clear that n is not a prime number 
* Explain what is | a - b |
Add a coma instead of doing two sentences too after "Given ..."
Otherwise seems good to me.

Goal section
* Please format a, b and n as [[variables]].

* Please add [[a]] < [[b]] here.

Constraints section
* Please delete the second constraint as it is part of the rules, not a constraint on what possible cases the players will need to handle.

Thanks.
It's not necessary to add these constraints, the goal is to minimize the distance between [[a]] and [[b]], so the solution `1 n` would only work in some cases
I changed the Validator 8 in order to be different than the Test 8.
Test 5 and Validator 5 are also the same.
Well spotted. I changed it too.
